sn48.10:4.3: The faculties of faith, energy, mindfulness, samādhi, and wisdom.
sn48.10:4.5: And what is the faculty of faith?
sn48.10:4.6: It’s when a noble disciple has faith in the Realized One’s awakening:
sn48.10:4.7: ‘That Blessed One is perfect, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme trainer of people, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
sn48.10:4.8: This is called the faculty of faith.
sn48.10:5.1: And what is the faculty of energy?
sn48.10:5.2: It’s when a mendicant lives with energy roused up for giving up unwholesome qualities and gaining wholesome qualities. They’re strong, firmly applied, not slacking off when it comes to developing wholesome qualities.
sn48.10:5.3: They generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and endeavor so that bad, unwholesome qualities don’t arise.
sn48.10:5.4: They generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and endeavor so that bad, unwholesome qualities that have arisen are given up.
sn48.10:5.5: They generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and endeavor so that wholesome qualities arise.
sn48.10:5.6: They generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and endeavor so that wholesome qualities that have arisen remain, are not lost, but increase, mature, and are completed by development.
sn48.10:5.7: This is called the faculty of energy.
sn48.10:6.1: And what is the faculty of mindfulness?
sn48.10:6.2: It’s when a noble disciple is mindful. They have utmost mindfulness and alertness, and can remember and recall what was said and done long ago.
sn48.10:6.3: They meditate by observing an aspect of the body, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn48.10:6.4: They meditate by observing an aspect of feelings …
sn48.10:6.6: principles, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn48.10:6.7: This is called the faculty of mindfulness.
sn48.10:7.1: And what is the faculty of samādhi?
sn48.10:7.2: It’s when a noble disciple, relying on letting go, gets samādhi, gets unification of mind.
sn48.10:7.3: Quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unwholesome qualities, they enter and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
sn48.10:7.4: As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of samādhi, with internal clarity and confidence, and unified mind, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.
sn48.10:7.5: And with the fading away of rapture, they enter and remain in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss’.
sn48.10:7.6: Giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, they enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
sn48.10:7.7: This is called the faculty of samādhi.
sn48.10:8.1: And what is the faculty of wisdom?
sn48.10:8.2: It’s when a noble disciple is wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering.
sn48.10:8.3: They truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.
sn48.10:8.4: This is called the faculty of wisdom.
